title-group.article-title: Among Spectators and Agents of History: Navigating through the Memory Sites of the Panama Canal

abstract.label: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Public history sites like the West Indian Museum of Panama and the Miraflores Visitors Center have different approaches to narrating the Panama Canal story, ranging from tales of man’s triumph over nature and celebratory discourses of nationalist victories, to testimonies of the racial histories silenced by official renderings of the past. Given the important role of museums as educational institutions, sites that inform public opinion, and representational platforms for national tourism, this article explores the relationship these institutions forge between visitors and canal history. Through a comparative analysis of the narratives and experiential strategies at each site, I evaluate the degree to which Panamanians are cast as spectators in grandiose histories of triumph, or as agents, responsible for shaping the past, present and future. In contrast to these physical sites, I consider how The Society of Friends of the West Indian Museum of Panama constructs a living past through memory practices that challenge the petrified histories traditionally found in museums.

ref.mixed-citation: According to Castillero Calvo, the majority of Panamanians share “a profoundly traditionalist, conservative and up to a certain point static notion of history: traditionalist, because it favors anecdotes over analyses and confuses history with timelines; conservative, because it shies away from revisionist approaches that question the tenets of an alleged national identity free of shadows and doubts; static, because it seems as if the past is framed as a finished event and that we cannot discover anything new” (translation mine, 1).
Pierre Nora posits that memory sites can be physical places, such as museums or cemeteries, practices, like commemorations or mottos, and even objects, like texts and symbols.

José Quiroga writes about the teleology of the Cuban Revolution as a “managed history” that comes to an abrupt and devastating halt in the Post-Soviet Era. This idea of the managed construction of nationalist historical narratives and chronologies, oriented toward a specific revolutionary or liberating end, is helpful to understanding how the canal's 1999 transfer is rendered as the culminating moment of Panama's struggle for sovereignty.
I examine a third museum,El Museo del Canal Interoceánico de Panamá(The Museum of the Inter-Oceanic Canal), in my dissertation, “Canal Memories: Race, Space and the Construction of Modern Panama.”

In a recent interview, Jelin reflected positively on the widespread use of her term “memory entrepreneurs.” This concept is intended to recognize the agency and subjectivity of social actors and movements often deemed as ephemeral: “with this idea I tried to go against a frequent posture in the most dominant or fashionable trends in cultural studies, in which cultural productions seem to circulate in a loud, without references, without actors who lead concrete projects. Cultural productions are analyzed as if they were in a cloud, eliminating historical subjects. My book is inclined exactly in the opposite direction, toward the study of concrete subjects over time” (translation mine, 108).

As Sturken elaborates, “American national identity, and the telling of American history, has been fundamentally based on a disavowal of the role played in world politics by the U.S. not simply as a world power, but as a nation with imperialist policies and aspirations to empire. This disavowal of the U.S. as an empire has allowed for the nation's dominant self-image as perennially innocent” (7).

All photographs taken by Emily F. Davidson (2011, 2012). The images of the Miraflores Visitor's Center are featured courtesy of the Panama Canal Authority. Photographs of the West Indian Museum of Panama are featured with permission from Panama's Office of Historical Patrimony.

For Arcadio Díaz Quiñones, reinterpretations of infamous dates are of utmost importance, and the crux of the matter is language. He argues that the title “The Spanish American War,” globally associated with 1898, serves to simplify or erase the fact that all aspects of life in Spain, Cuba, the Philippines, Puerto Rico and the United States were profoundly affected by the cultural and geopolitical implications of this date. In the case at hand, notorious dates like 1903, associated with Roosevelt's “taking” of Panama, or 1989, associated with “Operation Just Cause” and the removal of General Manuel Noriega, need to be reinterpreted and retold from multiple perspectives.

Ferdinand de Lesseps (1805–1894), the developer of the Suez Canal and President of the Panama Canal Company during the French construction era, and U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt (1858–1919), are frequently presented as the founding fathers of the Panama Canal. Standard canal timelines start with Lessep's failure to construct a sea-level passage, followed by Roosevelt's tenacious plight to ensure the triumph of North American engineering. See David McCullough and Julie Greene .

Phillipe Bunau-Varilla (1859–1940) was a French engineer who lobbied against the construction of a Nicaraguan canal and negotiated, on Panama's behalf, the 1903 Hay-Bunau-Varilla treaty, which granted the U.S. permission to build the canal. See David McCullough and Julie Greene .

William Crawford Gorgas (1854–1920) was a physician for the U.S. Army and chief sanitary officer of the canal project. He is lauded for his research on the role of mosquitoes in the transmission of yellow-fever and malaria. See David McCullough and Julie Greene .
Declared a World Heritage Site in 1997, Panama's colonial Old Town was founded by the Spanish in 1673 (“Archaeological Site”).

The Müller House, popularly referred to as “La Casa Miller” or the “Mullah Building,” was a tenement house built in Calidonia in 1910. The house is known for its peculiar triangular shape, fashioned after the transatlantic ships that traversed the canal. See Roberto Reid. In Pulido Ritter's novelRecuerdo Panamá(I Remember Panama), the narrator describes a panicked group of kids who franticly run to watch the 1972 demolition of the house. At one point in the narration, the building acquires its own voice, describing the people from all over the world who shared the universe between her walls: “I've given them the universe, I've protected them beneath my zinc roof, and my rooms never covered their ears so that men, originating from such different parts of the world, could speak the same language. Antilleans, Chinese, Hindis, Arabs, Greeks, Jews, Italians, and many more. And my wooden floors are not stained with a single drop of blood. Don't they realize that I am this city?” (translation mine, 116).

Jamaican activist, journalist, and entrepreneur, Marcus Garvey (1887–1940) was a leader in the Pan-Africanism and Black Nationalism movements and the founder of the Universal Negro Improvement Association and the African Communities League. He advocated for the unification of African diaspora throughout the world in the struggle for racial equality, socioeconomic progress, and nationhood. See Edmund David Cronon .

Son of a Barbadian father and a St. Lucian mother, George Westerman (1910–1988) was born in the Canal Zone in Colón. His leadership in the National Civic League, an organization loosely modeled after the NAACP, was key in movements against the Gold and Silver Roll segregation in the Canal Zone, and in reversing the aforementioned constitutional amendment (1941) that denied citizenship to West Indians born in Panama. See Michael L. Conniff .

An English/Spanish informational pamphlet distributed at the museum explains: “Membership in SAMAAP is open to any person residing in Panamá, or overseas, without distinction of race, creed or social status. The primary requirement is to have an interest in working to realize and/or finance the goals of the society” (The Society).
See Aleida Samaniego C.

Former Defense Forces general, politician, and CIA informant, Manuel Antonio Noriega (1934–) was a Panamanian strongman, whose removal from power was a primary objective of the North American Invasion of Panama. See John Dinges . In December 2011, after spending more than 20 years in prison in the U.S. and France, Noriega was extradited to Panama to serve sentences for embezzlement, corruption and murder. See Scott Sayare . Former members of the opposition group, the Civilian Crusade, victims advocacy groups from El Chorrillo, and families of former military officers (executed by Noriega for treason), are just a few of the groups who brought up unresolved questions about the Invasion upon the strongman's return.

OnDía de las trenzas(5–21–2012), Panamanians of diverse ethnic backgrounds defied school regulations and challenged the public pressure to straighten “bad” hair by proudly wearing cornrows and braids. See Roberto Quintero and Ángel López Guía .
